Let me start with the most
important and the best thing
that I get to say all day--
happy birthday to my mom.
[CHEERING, APPLAUSE]
Woo!

OK, hopefully, we've set the
mood for some celebration.

And now I'd love to invite
some reflectiveness.

So if you wouldn't mind, if
you could join me for just
a second in closing your eyes.
[EXHALES]
Tune in to the day.
Feel its gravity.
Feel its lightness.
Feel the heat.

Drink in the luck and
all of the hard work

that it took for
you to get here.
[BREATHES DEEPLY]
You can open your eyes.

I want to give some
thanks to the folks who

have made HBS possible for us,
to the deans and professors who

have enriched our minds,
to the faculty support

staff, the scribes,
the online learning

facilitators, the building
support staff, the food service

professionals, and everyone
else who make HBS hum.

And I'd love to give a
special shout-out to Claire,

my bestie from the
Spangler Grille,

sitting under one of
these beautiful trees
on your right-hand side.
[CHEERING, APPLAUSE]
Yes.

Every day when I walk into the
Grille, and Claire sees me,

and she says, how
are you doing, baby?
[LAUGHTER]

I know she genuinely
cares to know the answer.

You never know when your
kindness will really

affect someone or bring
a smile to their face,

as Claire has done
for me every day.
Thank you.
[CHEERING, APPLAUSE]

While HBS would not have been
possible without the folks

I just mentioned, it wouldn't
have even been a possibility

without each of you sitting in
the audience with your graduate.

For you, we are
forever grateful.

And to the folks who
are not present today,

whoever they are and
whatever their story,

I honor them, the impact that
they've had on our lives,

and their hand in
helping us become
better versions of ourselves.

And last, I've got
to thank section B.
[CHEERING]
There we go.
[APPLAUSE]

I've got to thank
section B for putting up

with me on my soapbox, which
I may be on again today,

for putting up with my roasts
and my endless references
to Pixar movies.

In a real HBS class, a section
mate stopped the discussion.

And she said, you
know what, Erik?
Life is not like a Pixar movie.
And you know what?
I disagree.
[LAUGHTER]

Right now, it very
much feels like it is.

For us to reflect on
this experience together,

I'd love to take us on a
stroll down memory lane,
or maybe better yet, a scroll.

Welcome to your
HBS For You Page.

OK, now that I have Gen Z's
attention, for the millennials,

welcome to your Vine
feed, the Gen Xers,

your Myspace bulletin board, and
for the boomers in the audience,

I've been told to invite you
to the 8-millimeter film party.
[LAUGHTER]
Come aboard.

OK, jokes aside, fire up the
imagination, pick a soundtrack,
and rewind with me back to 2022.
Swipe.

You opened your email
at noon Eastern to read,
"The answer is yes."
[SCREAMS SILENTLY]
[LAUGHTER]
Wow.
Swipe.

You arrived at Admitted Students
Weekend, teeth chattering,

either because of the
mock case or maybe

because of the mixture of
snow and hail pelting us.
Thanks a lot, Boston.

The first of many shivers
here, but maybe that one
was the most intense.
Swipe.

You ended up on a-- let's
call it a boat tour.
[LAUGHTER]

The Croatian Coast was
shockingly an amazing place

to meet your future
classmates, albeit of
questionable appropriateness.
Swipe.

You've settled into your
new home in Aldrich.

Butterflies flood your
stomach as you raise your hand
for the first time.

You make a comment that the
class guest says was brilliant.

And you leave there feeling
like an absolute genius.
Or maybe you flub a comment.
Nobody remembers anyway.
Swipe.

Third straight three-case
day, and you're
feeling squeezed beyond belief.

You're starting to do the math
of which of the three cases
you might be able to skim.
[LAUGHTER]

Swipe-- but wait, your
friend gives a My Take,

and you learn about a
whole new side of them.

The hug that you
share afterwards

feels more meaningful
than you'd expect

from a friendship
of three months.
Swipe.
Harvard-Yale, round 1.

You bopped around Cambridge
like you own the place.

And you rocked the crimson
with pride, unless, of course,
you went to Yale for undergrad.
[LAUGHTER]
So embarrassing.
[LAUGHS]
Swipe.

Back on campus for
the second semester.

You attend a weekend trip with
a club or an affinity group.

And you feel a
wave of connection

that makes the huge HBS
community feel a bit more cozy.
Swipe.

You're on your laptop uploading
every detail of your life story
into 12twenty.

Swipe the interviews
start rolling in.

Swipe-- ah, a half-finished
Rock Summer Fellows application
sits on your desktop.
No, no, no.

Swipe, swipe,
swipe, swipe, swipe.

We're getting out of that
part of the algorithm.

Too good a day
for that darkness.
Swipe.
OK, nice.
Now we're at FIELD.

You check Find My
Friends, and you

see HBS dotting every
corner of the globe.

Somehow, news is traveling
faster within the class than
at the Associated Press.
Swipe.

Summer break, a moment
of space from HBS.

You return to campus
and grab dinner

with a small group
of close friends.

And amazingly, they
already are starting
to feel like your family.
Swipe.
Existential crisis hits.

It's the middle of
the second year,

and you have no
idea where you're
going to be in a few months.

All of your friends say
they're in the same boat,

but somehow you still
feel like you're behind.

Swipe, but you're saved
by a classmate who

just got engaged or
married or had a baby.

You were one of the
first ones to know.

And you feel comfort and solace
knowing that you'll very soon

drop the modifier from
"business school friend."
Swipe.

Bridges, the last
week of school.

Walking back into your
first year classroom

felt like returning home
after too many months apart.

Even though you were just down
the hall from your section mates

all year, distance still
made the heart grow fonder.
And swipe-- wait, that's weird.

Adhavan and Michelle
are on stage?
Swipe up.
Here we are.
Welcome to class day.
TikTok live.
Everyone smile for the selfie.
[LAUGHTER]

I'll get both
sides, don't worry.
[LAUGHTER]
[APPLAUSE]
This side needs some love.

You better believe that
selfie is getting a frame
before the diploma does.
[LAUGHTER]

Naturally, the
question of the day

is, what was the point
of all of that swiping?

I think we've all wrestled with
that question at some point
since being at school.

A prior struggle I
had with it helps

give me some clarity
as I reflect today.

Swipe back to that
Tuesday afternoon
when we all got into HBS.

I read the news,
shouted to my sisters,
and facetimed with my parents.

In excitement, we made a plan
to visit Cambridge together
the next weekend.

That night, my dad texted me a
whiskey glass emoji and said,
you got into freaking Harvard.

Saturday of the same week,
I got a call around 7:00 PM.
Erik, Dad passed out.
Mom's worried.

I ran home and
joined my sisters.

We sprawled on the floor as we
phoned in to the paramedics,

talking my mom through what
was happening in the basement.
An agonizing hour unfolded.

Four days after I had gotten
into HBS, three years, one

month, and 19 days
ago, my father
died of a sudden heart attack.
[SNIFFLES]
[SIGHS]

Ken Roberts was my mentor, my
biggest cheerleader, my best
friend.

He was the kind of guy who
would drive to and from New York

eight hours to pick me up
when the pandemic started,

who bought a
co-worker's plane ticket

home when her mother passed
without a second thought.

He was the kind of guy with the
larger-than-life personality who

would light up a room
the instant he walked in,

whose dad jokes in a restaurant
were legitimately funny,

the kind of father who showed
up day after day for the people
that he loved.

When I lost him, the only
story that I could believe
was that my life was over too.

What was the point of
anything anymore if my dad
wasn't here to share it?

The following Monday,
I called HBS to say,
I wouldn't be coming here.
I just couldn't do it.

I spend months drowning
in sorrow every day,

sinking into a
deeper depression.

I wore a smile to feign that
things were OK around my family
and when I went back to work.

But every few minutes,
I would go numb,

remembering that I'm living
in a world without my father.
I still feel that way.

But there's another
side to the story.
It took me a while to find.

Losing my father
refocused my priorities.

It helped me see
what really mattered.

And it gave me the
deepest perspective

I could have ever wanted,
or maybe not wanted.

And the example he
set helps me see

what I would call the
essence, or the point,
of an experience like this.

As I see it, what we
did here had very little

to do with DCFs or cycle times,
and certainly not the value
stick.

The point of an
experience like this

is to give us the tools, the
experiences, and the connections

to expand our minds and
our circles of empathy.

But even more important will be
how you translate that learning

and growth into becoming a
better person and a better
leader.
And therein lies the rub.

The essence of HBS
will be defined

by how we choose to use
our expanded minds when

we leave this place to make
that positive difference
in the world.

To do this, we must accept
several responsibilities

that we now have, burdens that,
if we don't get them right,

threaten to blur the
impact of this degree.

And this is where my father's
wisdom comes in handy.

I'd like to offer a few Ken
Roberts-inspired reflections

on some of these
burdens that may

help us stay on the
great path that we're on.

Let's start with
the first burden--
humility.

Whether you like it or
not, when we leave here,

we walk around with a crimson
H tattooed onto our foreheads.

And because of that, it is our
responsibility to cultivate
and embody humility.

My dad taught me that humility
comes from knowing your value,

neither overestimating it, nor
underestimating it, believing

that you have more to
learn from every encounter

and taking pride in
changing your mind.

It means keeping that
student's mindset,

even when we wear
a leader's title.

In one of our very first
cases, Indra Nooyi from Pepsi

taught us that when
she goes to work,

she wears the metaphorical
crown of being the CEO.

But when she goes home, she
leaves the crown in the garage
and becomes just Indra.

It is an achievement to have
earned the crown that we
are undoubtedly wearing today.

But tomorrow, when we
toss our caps in the air,

I encourage you to imagine
tossing your crown with it too.

Second is the burden
of generosity.

My father never cared about
how much money he made in life.

It was all about
living below your means

and being selfless
with the time, talent,
and treasure that you have.

It is up to us now to
devote time and talent

to causes that push our
communities, our planet,
and humanity forward.

And it is our responsibility to
donate our treasure accordingly,

thinking not of charity, but
of solidarity and reciprocity.

In my calculation, there
will never be enough time.

And we could always
use more talent.

But consider whether there might
be a point at which we have more
treasure than we really need.

My challenge for all of us is
to think hard about how much you
can afford to give back.

And when you feel like
you've reached your limit,

could you push just
a little further?

A spirit of generosity
is cultivated over time.

And that first paycheck
when we leave this place

might be a great time
to nurture that spirit.

Finally, we are burdened with
the need to tell good stories,

especially in the
face of adversity.

Maybe you have tools to
deal with the tough moments

in your life, from your faith,
or a meditation practice,
or your own family's values.

Or maybe you've picked up some
tactics from our classmates,
as I certainly have.

It is clear to me that when
I choose to tell myself

better stories, more
thoughtful, nuanced,

and intentional stories, the
power that they have is immense.

Here are some of the new stories
that I've come to believe.

For starters, losing
my father has helped me
feel others' pain more fully.

Without it, I couldn't hold a
section mate quite as tightly
when they lose a parent too.

I wouldn't know what to say,
or that sometimes, there's

nothing to say, and all
you can do is show up.

Since his passing,
my father's voice

has gotten even
clearer in my head,

helping me feel more
conviction in my values

and what it means to
do the right thing.

If a thought creeps
in that says,

maybe I'll take
the easy way out.

Maybe I won't pick my
friend up from the airport.

Maybe I won't show up for
someone when they need me--

I hear his voice saying,
come on, brother,
you know what to do.

Last, my father's favorite
lesson from his own mother
was that life is for the living.
You can't waste a day of it.

As I healed, I
knew he would want

me to come here, have this
experience, and meet all of you.

And what a blessing
that has been.

We all know how
loving ends, said

Maurice Sendak, the author
of Where the Wild Things Are.
We all know how loving ends.

But I want to fall in
love with the world anyway
to let it crack me open.

I'm glad that the
world has cracked

me open, not for the
pain in my breastbone

or the tightness in my
throat, but for the way

that my mind and my
circle of empathy

are more expansive
because of it.

I wish like crazy that
those that we have lost

could physically be here
on a day like today.

But I feel confident
knowing that they are here.

At least, their essences
live on in each of us.

And I also know that
it wouldn't matter

if today, we were
graduating from Harvard
or kicking it on the couch.

The people who really loved
us would be just as proud
either way.

Before I let you go, I
want to take just a second

to put a piece of my own
advice into practice.

A few minutes ago,
I had said, we all

have three burdens
on our shoulders
upon walking out of here.

But what if I had picked
a different story?

What if I had said, we
have three privileges,
three new opportunities?

How might you have
experienced them differently?

Allow me the chance to choose
my words a bit more carefully.

Congratulations, class of
2024, on graduating from HBS.

We now have the
privilege of having
something to be humble about.

We have the privilege of
having something to give.

And we've had the privilege
of an education that

will help us craft better
stories about the world,

about our work, and
about our lives.

If we are known for
leading with humility,

giving generously, and
telling the very best stories,

it is undoubtedly
true that we are
headed to infinity and beyond.
Thank you so much.
[CHEERING, APPLAUSE]
